bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mary Fishback, September 6, 1940

div1.p: Hench asks for copies of newspaper articles about Reed's paper on yellow fever, presented in Indianapolis in October, 1900.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mary Fishback, September 6, 1940
div1.opener:
September 6, 1940
Miss Mary Fishback
Assistant, Reference Department
Indianapolis Public Library
Meridian at Saint Clair
Indianapolis, Indiana
My dear Miss Fishback:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how much I appreciated your letter in answer
to my inquiry regarding the newspaper coverage of Dr. Walter Reed's paper announcing
his discovery of the cause of yellow fever, in Indianapolis, in October, 1900.
The very absence of information in the paper is amusing and intriguing, and shows
how little we appreciate a new truth, and I believe for that reason if for no other.
I should like to have photostatic copies or typed copies of the articles that you
mentioned in the Indianapolis Journal, October 24, 1900, the Indianapolis Sentinel
for the same date, etc., whichever would be the easiest and cost the least. If you
wish to have someone type the articles, I shall be glad to pay the secretarial ex-
pense. I am particularly anxious to know what the headlines of these articles were.
Naturally, I don't want full details regarding the other papers read, but I would
like to have a general idea of how much newspaper space was allotted to the other
papers in contrast to that allotted to Walter Reed's paper.
May I again thank you for your courtesy in this matter.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
